Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Refining Research Challenges Underlying a National-Scale Learning Health System Anchored in a New Science of Cyber-Social Ecosystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This workshop is to assess the research needs and opportunities in the development and implementation of a national-scale Learning Health System (LHS). Realizing such a transformative vision represents a profound socio-technical challenge requiring not only collaboration among multiple and diverse stakeholders, but also a new cross-disciplinary science of cyber-social ecosystems to address the myriad novel scientific research challenges the LHS presents. The proposed workshop will be convened at a cross-disciplinary, integrative symposium on January 5-6, 2015 at the 48th International Conference on Systems Sciences (HICSS-48). Bringing together the workshop with this conference will leverage a unique opportunity to develop an understanding of the fundamental knowledge needed for the development of a LHS and the new cross-disciplinary science of cyber-social ecosystems within a broad scientific community, including those for information technology, systems science, healthcare and other non-related fields. The workshop is expected to have a significant impact on the development of a research agenda for a Learning Health System. Leveraging the multidisciplinary expertise at the HICSS-48 conference will be an important next step in moving this work forward and advancing a new science.

Updated: November, 2015

 

In recent years, our nation’s health system has grown increasingly digitized.  Health records that would have been recorded in paper form several years ago are now being captured electronically.  Fitness accessories and health monitoring sensors are also growing in popularity and ubiquity.  However, accompanying this historic investment of public and private resources into “digital health”, a broad-based consensus has emerged that maximum benefits from these data will accrue only if the captured data are shared in ways that enable valid and trustworthy knowledge to be generated from it – and in turn, if such knowledge is rapidly disseminated in actionable forms to clinicians and patients and other stakeholders to inform decisions affecting health.  This vision is known as the Learning Health System (LHS).  A nationwide LHS described in reports of the Institute of Medicine (IOM) dating to 2007, is now the overarching goal of the United States national health IT strategic planning for the coming decade.

 

Achieving an LHS is a grand challenge for the nation.  Realizing a high-functioning LHS requires the synergistic fusion of expertise from multiple and diverse disciplines – including computational, biomedical, information, system, physical, and social sciences – to address myriad scientific and engineering research challenges.  Perhaps the greatest inherent challenge is one of drawing upon perspectives from seemingly divergent disciplines, to work together to innovatively tackle such complex challenges none could address alone.  An NSF workshop, convened in Washington, DC in April, 2013, identified many of these challenges.  They were described in a 2014 paper in the Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association (JAMIA), “Toward a science of learning systems: a research agenda for the high-functioning Learning Health System” (http://jamia.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2014/11/07/amiajnl-2014-002977).

 

To build upon previous interdisciplinary collaborative work, the organizers planned and convened an LHS symposium at the 48th annual Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences (HICSS-48) on January 5-6, 2015 (http://lhs.medicine.umich.edu/lks/hicss48).  The symposium sought to bring and integrate further insights from system scientists and other scientists outside the healthcare arena to this collaborative work.  It paved a path for coalescing a global multi-disciplinary scientific community of interest around a new science of cyber-social learning systems and collaboratively envisioning next steps to grow this community and this corresponding emergent scientific discipline.
